title: California Fights to Contain Fires Before Winds Pick Back Up
text:
California firefighters raced to battle multiple blazes across the state ahead of a shift in conditions that will once again whip up strong, dry winds and fan flames, as utility companies planned to cut off power to more than half a million customers in preparation for the dangerous conditions.

In the northern part of the state, utility giant PG&E Corp. is expected to shut off power for nearly 600,000 customers on Tuesday—part of a round of intentional blackouts that have been implemented to decrease fire dangers. The bankrupt utility’s equipment has been cited as a potential cause in numerous past fires.

It is part of a new normal for Californians: Over the past month, wind-driven wildfires and mandatory blackouts have sent residents fleeing and businesses reeling from lost revenue.

Photos of the California Fires and Blackouts: What We Know

Winds in the area around the Kincade Fire in Sonoma County and surrounding areas—which is 15% contained and has grown to nearly 75,000 acres—are expected to kick up to around 15 to 25 miles an hour, with gusts up to 35 to 60 mph. During these conditions, dangerous flare ups can occur and flames can spread rapidly, sending embers as far as a mile in distance.

A red flag warning, issued by weather authorities when winds are high and humidity is low, has been issued for much of the state.

In the south, wind conditions are expected to be much worse, with the National Weather Service issuing an extreme red flag warning in the area from Tuesday evening through Thursday afternoon. Gusts in Los Angeles and Ventura counties are predicted to be between 50 mph and 70 mph, with some isolated areas experiencing winds of up to 80 mph.

Photos: Flames Rage as Winds Whip California Wildfires prompted the evacuation of tens of thousands of people over the weekend, and millions were left without power. A helicopter drops water on the Getty Fire in Los Angeles on Monday. etienne laurent/Shutterstock 1 of 17 • • • • • 1 of 17 Show Caption A helicopter drops water on the Getty Fire in Los Angeles on Monday. etienne laurent/Shutterstock

Southern California Edison, the main utility company in the south of the state, is considering shutting off power to more than 200,000 customers.

Firefighters in Los Angeles worked overnight to contain a fast-moving fire that erupted early Monday along the 405 freeway, a major thoroughfare that connects two major parts of the city. The Los Angeles Fire Department hoped to make progress on the Getty Fire, named for the area where it began near the Getty Museum, during a window of favorable conditions before the Santa Ana winds returned.

As of Monday evening, the fire was only 5% contained and had burned over 600 acres.

The Los Angeles Unified School District said all of the 19 schools that were closed Monday due to the blaze would be closed again Tuesday.

description: California firefighters raced to battle multiple blazes across the state ahead of a shift in conditions that will once again whip up strong, dry winds and fan flames, as utility companies planned more blackouts.
